message.content: Color is the property of visible light that depends on its wavelength. White light is not the absence of color, rather it is a combination of all colors of the visible spectrum. White light can be separated into its component colors using a prism, which shows all the colors of the spectrum. This phenomenon is called dispersion. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) no, white light is not the absence of color.

White light is actually a combination of all colors of visible light. This can be observed through a prism or a rainbow, where white light is dispersed into its various components of colors. Therefore, it cannot be the absence of color. Option (B) is the correct answer.

White light is actually a combination of all colors in the visible spectrum. When light passes through a prism, it splits into various colors - this is called a spectrum. White light is generally seen when light from various sources combine together. The reason behind this is that when all the different colors combine, they form white light. Hence, white light cannot be absence of color. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) no.

White light is a combination of all the colors of the visible spectrum. When light passes through a prism or is refracted, it separates into its different wavelengths of colors, creating a rainbow effect. Therefore, white light cannot be the absence of color since it contains all colors. The correct answer is (B) no.

Firstly, what is white light? White light is a combination of all the colors in the visible spectrum. When these colors are combined, they form white light. 

Now, if white light was the absence of color, this would mean that there are no colors present in white light. However, we just established that white light is actually a combination of all the colors in the visible spectrum. Therefore, white light cannot be the absence of color. 

Hence, the correct answer is (B) no.

White light is a combination of all the colors of the visible spectrum. When white light passes through a prism, it gets separated into the colors of the rainbow. This phenomenon is called dispersion. So, we can say that white light contains all the colors of the visible spectrum. Therefore, it cannot be the absence of color. Hence, the correct answer is (B) no.

White light is actually a mixture of all colors in the visible spectrum. When these colors are combined, the human eye sees them as white. So, white light is not the absence of color, but rather the presence of all colors. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) no.

White light is actually a combination of all the colors in the visible spectrum. This can be seen through a prism or a rainbow, where white light is separated into its various colors. Therefore, white light cannot be considered as the absence of color. It is rather a combination of all the colors. Thus, the correct answer to this question is (B) no.

Firstly, white light is the combination of all colors in the visible spectrum. This means that white light contains all colors, rather than being the absence of color. When white light passes through a prism, it splits into a rainbow spectrum of colors, proving that it is not the absence of color. Therefore, the correct answer to the question is (B) no.

White light is actually a combination of all colors in the visible spectrum. When light hits an object, certain wavelengths are absorbed and others are reflected. The color we see is the color of the light that is reflected off the object. When all the colors in the spectrum are reflected off an object, we see white. Therefore, white light isn't the absence of color but rather the presence of all colors. Hence, the correct answer is (B) no.
